anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 13 reads as follows Any tax assessed, or any other amount due under this Act from a dealer, may without prejudice to any other mode of companylection, be recovered-  a  as if it were an arrear of land revenue, or  b  on application to any Magistrate, by such Magistrate as if it were a fine imposed by him Provided that numberproceeding for such recovery shall be taken or companytinued as long as he has, in regard to the payment of such tax or other amount, as the case may be, companyplied with an order by any of the authorities to whom the dealer has appealed, or applied for revision, under sections 20, 21, 22- 23 or 24.

issues.text: whether the respondent is liable to be proceeded against under s. 29(1)(d) unless the requirements of the proviso to sub-s. (3) of s. 13 are satisfied

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chaudhuri refers to the proviso to sub-s.  3  of s. 13 and contends that unless the requirements of the proviso are satisfied he is number liable to be proceeded against under s. 29  1   d . In order to appreciate his argument it is desirable to reproduce the provision relied upon by him.

issues.text: whether by virtue of the proviso to sub-s. (3) of s. 13 an assessee will not be liable to be proceeded against unless it is shown that he has failed to comply with an order made by the appropriate authority under one of the sections referred to in the proviso

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chaudhury, however, contends that by virtue of the proviso an assessee will number be liable to be proceeded against unless it is shown that he has failed to companyply with an order made by the appropriate authority under one of the sections refered to in the proviso.

issues.text: whether in view of the fact that an appeal has been preferred the liability of the assessee to pay the tax must be deemed to have been suspended during the pendency of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chaudhury then contended that in view of the fact that an appeal has been preferred the liability of the assessee to pay the tax must be deemed to have been suspended during the pendency of the appeal. This argument ignores the specific provisions of sub-s.  5  of s. 20 and the proviso thereto.

arguments.claim: proviso to s.13(3) affords interim protection from recovery under cl.(a) or (b) only if complies with order of appellate authority

anchor.surface_text: The assessee who has moved the appropriate authority under one of the provisions referred to in the proviso has, however, been afforded interim protection from action under cl.  a  or cl.  b  provided that he approaches the appropriate authority and obtains from that authority an order of stay of proceedings under cl.  a  or cl.  b . That, however, is number enough. If the order of the appropriate authority lays down any condition the proviso requires that the assessee must comply with those conditions before he can obtain interim relief under the proviso.

arguments.claim: proviso to s.13(3) not defence to prosecution under s.29(1)(d); offence is failure to pay within time in notice of demand

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that, we fail to see how the proviso to sub-s.  3  of s. 13 can at all be an answer to a prosecution under s. 29  1   d . What is rendered an offence under s. 29  1   d  is the failure of the assessee to pay the tax within the time allowed. But where, as here, the assessee has number paid the tax within the time allowed by a numberice of demand he immediately renders himself liable to be proceeded against under s. 29  1   d .

arguments.claim: liability to pay tax created by assessment order; non-payment despite demand notice triggers s.29(1)(d) irrespective of appeal

anchor.surface_text: The liability to pay tax is created by the order of assessment. Where tax so assessed is number paid despite service of numberice of demand the substantive portion of sub-s.  3  of s. 13 renders the assessee liable to be proceeded against under cl.  a  or cl.  b  of that provision.

arguments.claim: s.20(5) complete answer to contention that appeal suspends payment obligation

anchor.surface_text: The provision we have just quoted is a companyplete answer to Mr. Chaudhuris companytention.
There is numbersubstance in this companytention. We are, therefore clear that the acquittal of the respondent for offences in the case was unwarranted.

holdings.text: The proviso to sub-s. (3) of s. 13 does not create liability to pay tax or protect from prosecution under s. 29(1)(d); liability arises from assessment order and non-payment despite notice of demand.

anchor.surface_text: The liability to pay tax is created by the order of assessment. Where tax so assessed is number paid despite service of numberice of demand the substantive portion of sub-s.  3  of s. 13 renders the assessee liable to be proceeded against under cl.  a  or cl.  b  of that provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects construction of proviso as creating liability; substantive s.13(3) triggers recovery on non-payment post-demand notice.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.13(3) affords interim protection from recovery under cl.(a) or (b) only if assessee obtains stay order from appellate authority and complies with its conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee who has moved the appropriate authority under one of the provisions referred to in the proviso has, however, been afforded interim protection from action under cl.  a  or cl.  b  provided that he approaches the appropriate authority and obtains from that authority an order of stay of proceedings under cl.  a  or cl.  b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso requires active step by assessee to seek and comply with authority's order for protection; no automatic stay.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.13(3) is no defence to prosecution under s.29(1)(d), which is triggered by failure to pay tax within time specified in notice of demand.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that, we fail to see how the proviso to sub-s.  3  of s. 13 can at all be an answer to a prosecution under s. 29  1   d . What is rendered an offence under s. 29  1   d  is the failure of the assessee to pay the tax within the time allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes recovery under s.13(3) from criminal offence under s.29(1)(d); proviso limited to recovery modes.

holdings.text: Preferring appeal under s.20(1) does not suspend liability to pay assessed tax; s.20(5) mandates payment notwithstanding appeal unless appellate authority directs otherwise on furnishing security.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chaudhury then companytended that in view of the fact that an appeal has been preferred the liability of the assessee to pay the tax must be deemed to have been suspended during the pendency of the appeal. This argument ignores the specific provisions of sub-s.  5  of s. 20

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit terms of s.20(5) and proviso override any general suspension; requires security for deferral.

holdings.text: Respondent's failure to pay tax despite knowledge of demand notices constituted wilful default.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent knew that he was required to pay the tax within certain time and also knew that he had number companyplied with the numberice of demand. His action in number paying the tax was quite clearly deliberate and, therefore, wilful.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent aware of obligation and deliberately non-compliant.

holdings.text: Acquittal of respondent under s.29(1)(d) by Magistrate and High Court was unwarranted.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance in this companytention. We are, therefore clear that the acquittal of the respondent for offences in the case was unwarranted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erred in holding pendency of appeals bars prosecution; statutory provisions mandate liability and offence.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore clear that the acquittal of the respondent for offences in the case was unwarranted. We would, therefore, have, after setting aside his acquittal in each of the three cases, companyvicted and sentenced him under s. 29 1 d of the Act but for the fact that when special leave was granted an undertaking was given by the State that irrespective of the result of the appeal the respondent would number be prosecuted.

Where tax so assessed is number paid despite service of numberice of demand the substantive portion of sub-s.  3  of s. 13 renders the assessee liable to be proceeded against under cl.  a  or cl.  b  of that provision.

We are, therefore clear that the acquittal of the respondent for offences in the case was unwarranted. We would, therefore, have, after setting aside his acquittal in each of the three cases, companyvicted and sentenced him under s. 29 1 d of the Act but for the fact that when special leave was granted an undertaking was given by the State that irrespective of the result of the appeal the respondent would number be prosecuted.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee who has moved the appropriate authority under one of the provisions referred to in the proviso has, however, been afforded interim protection from action under cl.  a  or cl.  b  provided that he approaches the appropriate authority and obtains from that authority an order of stay of proceedings under cl.  a  or cl.  b .

We are, therefore clear that the acquittal of the respondent for offences in the case was unwarranted. We would, therefore, have, after setting aside his acquittal in each of the three cases, companyvicted and sentenced him under s. 29 1 d of the Act but for the fact that when special leave was granted an undertaking was given by the State that irrespective of the result of the appeal the respondent would number be prosecuted.
